sections.heading: What is React?
paragraphs: React is a JavaScript library for building user interfaces.
React is used to build single-page applications.
React allows developers to create reusable UI components.

sections.heading: Learning by Examples
paragraphs: The React examples show both the code and the result.
This helps you understand how React works in real applications.

sections.heading: Learning by Exercises
paragraphs: Many chapters include exercises to test your React knowledge.

You can also earn badges and maintain learning streaks.

CSS
JavaScript

sections.heading: Get Certified

Certification helps validate your React skills.

sections.heading: What is React?
paragraphs: React is a front-end JavaScript library.
React was developed by Facebook Software Engineer Jordan Walke.
React is also known as React.js or ReactJS.
React is used to build user interface components.

sections.heading: How Does React Work?
paragraphs: React creates a Virtual DOM in memory.
Instead of manipulating the browser DOM directly, React updates a virtual DOM first.
React compares changes and updates only what needs to be changed in the real DOM.
This process improves performance and efficiency.

sections.heading: What You Should Already Know
paragraphs: Before learning React, you should have a basic understanding of the following:
HTML
CSS
JavaScript

sections.heading: React.JS History
paragraphs: The latest version of React is 19.0.0 (December 2024).
React was first released to the public in July 2013.
React was initially used in 2011 for Facebook's News Feed.
Jordan Walke, a Facebook Software Engineer, created React.

sections.heading: Prerequisites
paragraphs: To use React in production, you need npm which is included with Node.js.
You also need to set up a React environment and choose a build tool.

sections.heading: Setting Up a React Environment
paragraphs: First, make sure you have Node.js installed.
You can check the installation by running the following command in your terminal:
node -v
If Node.js is installed, the version number will be displayed.
If Node.js is not installed, you need to install it before continuing.

sections.heading: Install a Build Tool (Vite)
paragraphs: After installing Node.js, you can create a React application using a build tool.
In this tutorial, the Vite build tool is used.
Install Vite globally using the following command:
npm install -g create-vite
If the installation is successful, a confirmation message will be shown.

sections.heading: Create a React Application
paragraphs: Run the following command to create a React application named my-react-app:
npm create vite@latest my-react-app -- --template react
If prompted to install additional packages, press y and Enter to continue.
Once completed, instructions to navigate and run the project will be displayed.

sections.heading: Install Dependencies
paragraphs: Navigate to the project directory:
cd my-react-app
Install the required dependencies using:
npm install
This will install all necessary packages for the React application.

sections.heading: Run the React Application
paragraphs: Start the development server using the following command:
npm run dev
The terminal will display a local development URL.
Open your browser and navigate to the displayed URL to see your React application running.

sections.heading: Exercise
paragraphs: What command can you use to check if Node.js is installed on your system?
Correct answer: node -v

sections.heading: Introduction
paragraphs: Now that your development environment is set up, you can modify the default React app.
The goal is to display a simple Hello World message.

sections.heading: Modify the React App
paragraphs: Open the my-react-app directory.
Inside it, locate the src folder.
In the src folder, open the App.jsx file.

sections.heading: Default App.jsx File
paragraphs: The App.jsx file initially contains default Vite and React boilerplate code.
This code includes logos, a counter example, and hot module replacement support.

sections.heading: Replace App.jsx Content
paragraphs: Replace the entire content of the App.jsx file with the following code:

function App() { return (

Hello World!

); } export default App;
Save the file after replacing the code.

sections.heading: View the Result
paragraphs: After saving the file, the browser will update automatically.
You do not need to reload the page manually.
You should now see Hello World displayed in the browser.

sections.heading: Conclusion
paragraphs: Congratulations! You have successfully modified your first React application.

sections.heading: Exercise
paragraphs: In which directory can you find the App.jsx file?
Correct answer: my-react-app/src

sections.heading: Introduction
paragraphs: React's goal is to render HTML in a web page.
React renders HTML through a container using the createRoot() function.

sections.heading: The Container
paragraphs: React uses a container element to render HTML.

Usually, this container is a
in the index.html file.
The container defines where the React content will be displayed.

sections.heading: index.html File
paragraphs: The index.html file contains the root container for the React application.
Unnecessary code can be removed to simplify learning React.
The minimal index.html includes only the root element and the script reference.

sections.heading: The createRoot Function
paragraphs: The createRoot function is located in the src/main.jsx file.
It is used to create a root node for the React application.
The function takes an HTML element as its argument.

sections.heading: Rendering Content
paragraphs: The render method defines what content should be displayed.
The rendered content appears inside the container element.
You can render headings, paragraphs, or any JSX element.

sections.heading: JSX and HTML Code
paragraphs: React uses JSX, which allows HTML-like syntax in JavaScript.
JSX elements can be stored in variables and rendered.
Complex HTML structures like tables can be rendered using JSX.

sections.heading: The Root Node
paragraphs: The root node is the container managed by React.
It does not have to be a div element.
It does not have to use the id 'root', although it is the common convention.

sections.heading: Conclusion
paragraphs: React renders HTML efficiently using a virtual DOM.
The createRoot and render methods control how and where content appears.

sections.heading: Exercise
paragraphs: What is true about the container element for React rendering?
Correct answer: It can have any ID, but 'root' is a common convention.

sections.heading: Introduction
paragraphs: This section explains how to upgrade an existing React application to React version 19.
If you are already using the latest version of React, you can skip this section.

sections.heading: Upgrade to React 19
paragraphs: Upgrading to React 19 requires only two simple steps.
These steps ensure your application can use the latest React features.

sections.heading: Step 1: Install React 19
paragraphs: Navigate to your project folder.
Run the following command in the terminal to install the latest React and React DOM versions:
npm i react@latest react-dom@latest

sections.heading: Step 2: Use the New Root API
paragraphs: React 19 introduces a new root API for client rendering.
Using the new API enables concurrent features in React.

sections.heading: Before Upgrade
paragraphs: Older React versions use ReactDOM.render for rendering components.
This approach behaves like React 17 even when using newer versions.

sections.heading: After Upgrade
paragraphs: The new approach uses createRoot from react-dom/client.
The createRoot method replaces ReactDOM.render for modern React applications.

sections.heading: Important Note
paragraphs: Your application will still work if you continue using ReactDOM.render.
However, it will not benefit from React 19's concurrent features unless you use the new root API.

sections.heading: Conclusion
paragraphs: Upgrading React is simple and improves future compatibility.
Using the new root API ensures your application behaves as expected in React 19.

sections.heading: What is ES6?
paragraphs: ES6 stands for ECMAScript 6.
ECMAScript was created to standardize JavaScript.
ES6 is the 6th version of ECMAScript, published in 2015.
ES6 is also known as ECMAScript 2015.

sections.heading: Why Should I Learn ES6?
paragraphs: React uses ES6 syntax and features extensively.
Understanding ES6 makes React code easier to read and write.
Learning ES6 is essential for modern JavaScript and React development.

sections.heading: Important ES6 Features Used in React
Conclusion
paragraphs: ES6 introduced powerful features that simplify JavaScript coding.
React applications heavily rely on ES6 features.
Mastering ES6 will help you become a better React developer.

sections.heading: What is JSX?
paragraphs: JSX stands for JavaScript XML.
JSX allows developers to write HTML inside JavaScript code.
JSX makes it easier to write and add HTML in React applications.

sections.heading: Coding JSX
paragraphs: JSX lets you write HTML elements directly in JavaScript without using createElement() or appendChild().
JSX converts HTML tags into React elements.
Using JSX is optional, but it greatly simplifies React development.

sections.heading: JSX vs Without JSX
paragraphs: JSX allows HTML to be written directly inside JavaScript.
Without JSX, React.createElement() must be used.
JSX is based on ES6 and is compiled into standard JavaScript.

sections.heading: Expressions in JSX
paragraphs: JavaScript expressions can be written inside curly braces {} in JSX.
Expressions can include variables, properties, or any valid JavaScript code.
JSX evaluates the expression and displays the result.

sections.heading: Inserting a Large Block of HTML
paragraphs: Multiple lines of HTML must be wrapped inside parentheses.
This allows better formatting and readability.

sections.heading: One Top Level Element
paragraphs: JSX requires all elements to be wrapped inside a single parent element.
Fragments can be used to avoid adding extra elements to the DOM.

sections.heading: Elements Must Be Closed
paragraphs: JSX follows XML rules.
All elements must be properly closed, including self-closing tags.

sections.heading: class vs className
paragraphs: The class attribute is reserved in JavaScript.
JSX uses className instead of class.
JSX converts className into class when rendering HTML.

sections.heading: Comments in JSX
paragraphs: Comments in JSX are written using the {/* */} syntax.
Comments can be embedded inside JSX elements.

sections.heading: JSX in React Components
paragraphs: React components are reusable pieces of UI.
Components return JSX to describe what should appear on the screen.
JavaScript logic can be written inside components before returning JSX.

sections.heading: Conclusion
paragraphs: JSX simplifies writing UI code in React.
It improves readability and maintainability.
Mastering JSX is essential for building React applications.

sections.heading: Overview
paragraphs: One of the most powerful features of JSX is the ability to embed JavaScript expressions directly within markup.
JSX allows dynamic values to be calculated and displayed inside React components.

sections.heading: Expressions
paragraphs: Any valid JavaScript expression can be inserted inside JSX using curly braces {}.
React evaluates the expression and renders the result in the DOM.

sections.heading: Variables in JSX
paragraphs: Variables can be used as JSX expressions.
Wrap variables in curly braces to display their values inside JSX.

sections.heading: Function Calls
paragraphs: Functions can be called inside JSX expressions.
This allows logic to be reused when rendering values dynamically.

sections.heading: Object Properties
paragraphs: Object properties can be accessed inside JSX.
This is useful when displaying structured data in components.

sections.heading: Exercise Concept
paragraphs: JSX expressions must be written inside curly braces.
Mathematical expressions should be evaluated inside JSX using {}.

sections.heading: Key Takeaways
paragraphs: JSX expressions make React components dynamic.
They support variables, function calls, calculations, and object access.
Understanding JSX expressions is essential for effective React development.

sections.heading: Overview
paragraphs: JSX allows attributes to be added to HTML elements, similar to HTML.
However, there are important differences because JSX is written in JavaScript.

sections.heading: class vs className
paragraphs: The HTML class attribute cannot be used directly in JSX.
Since class is a reserved JavaScript keyword, JSX uses className instead.
JSX converts className into class when rendering to the browser.

sections.heading: Expressions as Attributes
paragraphs: JSX allows JavaScript expressions to be used as attribute values.
Expressions must be written inside curly braces {}.
When using expressions, attribute values should not be wrapped in quotes.

sections.heading: camelCase Event Attributes
paragraphs: Event attributes in JSX use camelCase naming.
For example, onclick becomes onClick in JSX.

sections.heading: Boolean Attributes
paragraphs: If an attribute is written without a value, JSX treats it as true.
To explicitly set false, the attribute must be assigned a false expression.

sections.heading: The style Attribute
paragraphs: The style attribute in JSX accepts a JavaScript object, not a CSS string.
CSS properties are written in camelCase, such as fontSize instead of font-size.
Styles are commonly stored in an object and passed using curly braces.

sections.heading: Exercise Concept
paragraphs: Correct JSX attribute names include style, className, and onClick.
Using correct attribute syntax is essential for JSX to work properly.

sections.heading: Key Takeaways
paragraphs: JSX attributes differ slightly from HTML attributes.
camelCase and JavaScript expressions are fundamental to JSX.
Understanding JSX attributes helps build dynamic and interactive React components.

sections.heading: Overview
paragraphs: React supports conditional logic using JavaScript.
However, traditional if statements cannot be written directly inside JSX.

sections.heading: Conditions in React
paragraphs: To use conditions with JSX, logic must be written outside the JSX block.
Alternatively, conditional expressions such as ternary operators can be used inside JSX.

sections.heading: Option 1: If Statements Outside JSX
paragraphs: You can write if statements before the return statement.
The result can then be rendered using a variable inside JSX.

sections.heading: Option 2: Ternary Expressions
paragraphs: Ternary expressions allow conditional rendering inside JSX.
They follow the format: condition ? valueIfTrue : valueIfFalse.

sections.heading: Using Expressions in JSX
paragraphs: Any JavaScript expression inside JSX must be wrapped in curly braces {}.
This applies to ternary expressions and variable rendering.

sections.heading: Exercise Concept
paragraphs: Ternary expressions are commonly used for simple conditional rendering.
They help display different outputs based on a condition.

sections.heading: Key Takeaways
paragraphs: If statements cannot be used directly inside JSX.
Conditional logic should be handled outside JSX or using ternary expressions.
Mastering conditional rendering is essential for dynamic React applications.

sections.heading: Overview
paragraphs: Components are like JavaScript functions that return HTML elements.
They are the building blocks of React applications.

sections.heading: What Are React Components
paragraphs: React components are independent and reusable pieces of code.
They work in isolation and return HTML to describe the UI.

sections.heading: Types of Components
paragraphs: There are two types of components: Class components and Function components.
Modern React recommends using Function components with Hooks.
Class components are still supported but are less commonly used.

sections.heading: Creating a Component
paragraphs: A React component name must start with an uppercase letter.
Function components return JSX (HTML-like syntax).

sections.heading: Rendering a Component
paragraphs: Components are rendered by referring to them like HTML tags.
Self-closing syntax is used when rendering components.

sections.heading: Props (Properties)
paragraphs: Props allow data to be passed into components.
Props are passed as attributes and accessed inside the component.

sections.heading: Components Inside Components
paragraphs: React components can be nested inside other components.
This helps build complex UIs from small reusable pieces.

sections.heading: Rendering Components Multiple Times
paragraphs: A component can be rendered more than once.
Props can be used to display different data for each instance.

sections.heading: Components in Separate Files
paragraphs: Components can be placed in separate .jsx files for better organization.
The file name must start with an uppercase letter.
Components must be exported and imported before use.

sections.heading: Exercise Concept
paragraphs: Components are rendered using self-closing JSX syntax.
Correct syntax is required to display a component properly.

sections.heading: Key Takeaways
paragraphs: Components are reusable UI elements in React.
Function components are the modern standard.
Props make components dynamic and flexible.
Proper component structure improves maintainability.

sections.heading: Introduction
paragraphs: Before React 16.8, Class components were the only way to manage state and lifecycle methods.
Function components were previously considered stateless.

sections.heading: Class Components vs Function Components
paragraphs: With the introduction of Hooks, Function components can now manage state and lifecycle features.
Function components are preferred in modern React development.
Class components are still supported and not planned for removal.

sections.heading: What Are React Class Components
paragraphs: Class components are reusable pieces of code that extend React.Component.
They return HTML using a render() method.

sections.heading: Creating a Class Component
paragraphs: Component names must start with an uppercase letter.
A class component must extend React.Component.
The render() method is required and returns JSX.

sections.heading: Rendering a Class Component
paragraphs: Class components are rendered using JSX syntax.
They are used like regular HTML tags.

sections.heading: Constructor in Class Components
paragraphs: The constructor() method runs when the component is initialized.
It is used to initialize state and bind methods.
The super() method must be called to access React.Component features.

sections.heading: State in Class Components
paragraphs: Component data is stored in an object called state.
State is accessed using this.state inside the component.

sections.heading: Using State in Render Method
paragraphs: State values can be displayed inside JSX.
State makes components dynamic and interactive.

sections.heading: Props in Class Components
paragraphs: Props allow data to be passed into components.
Props are accessed using this.props.

sections.heading: Props in the Constructor
paragraphs: Props must be passed to the constructor when used.
Props are forwarded to React.Component using super(props).

sections.heading: Components Inside Components
paragraphs: Class components can be nested inside other components.
This allows building complex user interfaces from smaller pieces.

sections.heading: Key Takeaways
paragraphs: Class components extend React.Component.
They use render() to return JSX.
State and props control component behavior.
Function components with Hooks are now preferred.

sections.heading: Introduction to Props
paragraphs: Props are arguments passed into React components.
Props are passed to components via HTML attributes.
Props stands for properties.
React props are similar to function arguments in JavaScript and attributes in HTML.

sections.heading: Passing Props to a Component
paragraphs: Props are passed to components using HTML-like attributes.

sections.heading: Receiving Props in a Component
paragraphs: Props are received as an object inside the component function.

sections.heading: Using a Different Props Name
paragraphs: The props object can be named anything.

sections.heading: Passing Multiple Props
paragraphs: You can pass multiple values as props.
Each attribute becomes a property of the props object.

sections.heading: Using Multiple Props
Passing Different Data Types
paragraphs: Strings are passed using quotes.
Numbers, variables, objects, and arrays must be passed using curly braces.

sections.heading: Passing Variables
Passing Objects and Arrays
Object Props Example
Array Props Example
Passing Props Between Components
Important Notes
points: You cannot modify props inside a component.
Props flow from parent to child components.

sections.heading: Introduction
paragraphs: Destructuring props allows you to extract specific properties from the props object.
It helps make code cleaner and easier to read.
React uses JavaScript destructuring syntax.

sections.heading: Destructuring in Function Parameters
paragraphs: You can destructure props directly in the function parameter list.
Only the required properties are extracted.

sections.heading: Destructuring Inside the Component
paragraphs: You can also destructure props inside the function body.
This allows access to multiple properties.

sections.heading: Using Rest Operator (...rest)
paragraphs: The rest operator collects remaining properties into an object.
Useful when you do not know how many props will be passed.

sections.heading: Default Values in Destructuring
paragraphs: Default values are used when a prop is not passed.
This prevents undefined values.

sections.heading: Exercise
paragraphs: Complete the code to destructure props in the function parameter.

sections.heading: Key Points
points: Destructuring makes code cleaner and more readable.
You can destructure in function parameters or inside the function.
The rest operator (...) collects remaining props.
Destructuring works only with object properties.

sections.heading: Introduction
paragraphs: In React, you can pass content between the opening and closing tags of a component.
This content is accessed using the props.children property.
It allows components to be reusable and flexible.

sections.heading: Using props.children
paragraphs: The children content is passed from the parent component.
It is rendered inside the child component using props.children.

sections.heading: How props.children Works
points: It allows passing JSX between component tags.
It works like a placeholder inside the component.
Any valid JSX can be passed as children.

sections.heading: Exercise
paragraphs: Complete the code to display the content of props.

sections.heading: Key Points
points: props.children holds the content between component tags.
It is commonly used for layouts and reusable components.
Children can be text, elements, or other components.
No need to define children explicitly in props.

sections.heading: Introduction
paragraphs: React events are similar to HTML DOM events.
They allow React components to respond to user actions like clicks, typing, and mouse movements.
React uses camelCase for event names.

sections.heading: Adding Events
paragraphs: React events use camelCase instead of lowercase.
Event handlers are written inside curly braces.
You pass a function reference, not a function call.
sections.code: <button onClick={shoot}>Take the Shot!</button>

sections.heading: Basic Event Example
Passing Arguments
paragraphs: To pass arguments to an event handler, use an arrow function.
This prevents the function from running immediately.

sections.heading: React Event Object
paragraphs: React automatically passes an event object to event handlers.
The event object contains information about the triggered event.

sections.heading: Exercise
paragraphs: Which is the correct way to add a mouseover event in React?
sections.answer: Lorum Ipsum

sections.heading: Key Points
points: Event handlers are written using curly braces.
Arrow functions are used to pass arguments.
The event object is automatically passed to handlers.
React events behave similarly to DOM events.

sections.heading: Introduction
paragraphs: In React, components can be rendered conditionally.
Conditional rendering works the same way conditions work in JavaScript.

sections.heading: Using if Statement
paragraphs: You can use a normal JavaScript if statement to decide which component to render.

sections.heading: Logical AND (&&) Operator
paragraphs: The && operator renders the right-hand component only if the condition is true.
If the condition is false, nothing is rendered.

sections.heading: Ternary Operator
paragraphs: The ternary operator is useful for conditional rendering inside JSX.
Syntax: condition ? true : false

sections.heading: Exercise
sections.question: Which one of these is a correct conditional rendering example?

sections.heading: Key Points
points: Conditional rendering works like JavaScript conditions.
Use if statements for complex logic.
Use ternary operator for inline conditions.
JSX expressions must return valid elements.

sections.heading: Introduction
paragraphs: In React, lists are rendered using JavaScript loops.
The most commonly used method for rendering lists is the map() function.
The map() method allows you to transform arrays into JSX elements.

sections.heading: Rendering Lists with map()
paragraphs: You can use the JavaScript map() method to render lists in React.
Each item in the array is converted into a JSX element.

sections.heading: Keys in React Lists
paragraphs: Keys help React identify which items have changed, are added, or removed.
Keys must be unique among sibling elements.
Using keys improves performance and prevents rendering issues.

sections.heading: Using Array Index as Key
paragraphs: Using array index as a key is not recommended for dynamic lists.
It should only be used when the list is static and items will not change order.
If items have unique IDs, always prefer those instead of indexes.

sections.heading: Exercise
sections.question: Which statement is NOT correct?
options: Keys must be unique to each sibling.
Keys can be the array index.
sections.answer: Keys cannot be a number.

sections.heading: Key Points
points: React lists are created using the map() function.
Each list item should have a unique key.
Using array index as key is discouraged unless the list is static.
Keys do not need to be globally uniqueonly unique among siblings.

sections.heading: Introduction
paragraphs: React uses forms to allow users to interact with web pages.
Forms in React work differently than traditional HTML forms.
React uses component state to control form data.

sections.heading: Adding Forms in React
paragraphs: Forms in React are created just like normal HTML forms.
However, React prevents default form submission behavior.

sections.heading: HTML Forms vs React Forms
paragraphs: In HTML, form elements manage their own state.
In React, form data is handled using component state.
This makes React forms predictable and easier to control.

sections.heading: Controlled Components
paragraphs: A controlled component is a form element whose value is controlled by React state.
The useState hook is used to store and update form values.
This provides a single source of truth for form data.

sections.heading: Initial Values
paragraphs: You can set an initial value for a form input using useState.
This value will be shown when the component loads.

sections.heading: Exercise
sections.question: Complete the code to create a controlled input:
sections.answer: value={x}

sections.heading: Key Points
points: Form data is stored in component state.
useState is used to manage input values.
Controlled components make form handling predictable.

sections.heading: Submitting Forms
paragraphs: In React, form submission can be controlled using the onSubmit event.
This allows you to prevent page reload and handle form data manually.

sections.heading: Handling Form Submission
paragraphs: You can attach an event handler to the onSubmit attribute of a form.
The event object allows you to prevent the default browser behavior.
The submitted data can then be processed using React state.

sections.heading: Explanation
points: onSubmit is used instead of onclick.
event.preventDefault() stops the page from refreshing.
The form is fully controlled by React.

sections.heading: Key Points
points: Always prevent default form behavior in React.
Use controlled components for form inputs.
Handle submit logic inside a function.
Forms in React are easier to validate and manage.

sections.heading: Textarea
paragraphs: The textarea element in React works differently compared to plain HTML.
In HTML, the text is placed between opening and closing textarea tags.
In React, the textarea value is controlled using the value attribute, just like input elements.

sections.heading: Controlled Textarea
paragraphs: React uses the useState hook to control the value of a textarea.
The value of the textarea is stored in state and updated using an onChange handler.

sections.heading: Explanation
points: onChange updates the state whenever the user types.
value binds the textarea to React state.
This makes the textarea a controlled component.

points: Textarea in React uses the value attribute.
onChange is required to update the value.
Controlled components give better form control.

sections.heading: Select
paragraphs: A dropdown list (select box) in React works differently than in plain HTML.
In HTML, the selected option is defined using the selected attribute.
In React, the selected value is controlled using the value attribute on the select element.

sections.heading: Controlled Select Element
paragraphs: React controls the selected option using state.
The value attribute is bound to a state variable.
The onChange handler updates the state when the selection changes.

sections.heading: Explanation
points: The value attribute controls which option is selected.
onChange updates the state when the user selects a new option.
This makes the select element a controlled component.

points: React uses the value attribute instead of selected.
Select elements are controlled using state.
onChange is required to update the selected value.
Controlled inputs provide predictable form behavior.

sections.heading: Handling Multiple Inputs
paragraphs: When a form contains multiple input fields, it is common to store all values in a single state object.
This approach is more scalable than using multiple useState hooks.
Each input field must have a unique name attribute.

sections.heading: Using One State Object
paragraphs: The useState hook can store an object that holds all input values.
Each change updates only the relevant field using object spread syntax.

sections.heading: Explanation
points: A single state object stores all input values.
The name attribute identifies which field changed.
Bracket notation updates only the changed field.

sections.heading: Initial Values
paragraphs: You can define default values by initializing the state object with properties.

points: Use a single state object for multiple inputs.

This approach is best for large forms.

sections.heading: Checkbox
paragraphs: Checkboxes in React are handled differently than text inputs.
Instead of using the value attribute, checkboxes use the checked attribute.
The checked attribute is controlled using state.

sections.heading: Using Checkbox with useState
paragraphs: The checked property determines whether the checkbox is selected.
The event handler must check the input type to determine the correct value.

sections.heading: Initial Values
paragraphs: Checkbox values can be pre-filled by setting initial values in useState.

sections.question: Complete the code to handle a checkbox input:

points: Checkboxes use the checked attribute instead of value.
Use e.target.checked to read checkbox state.
Checkbox state should be stored as boolean values.
Multiple inputs can be managed using a single state object.
Always bind checked and onChange for controlled components.

sections.heading: Radio Buttons
paragraphs: Radio buttons are used when only one option should be selected.
All radio buttons in a group must share the same name attribute.
The checked attribute is used to control which option is selected.

sections.heading: Using Radio Buttons in React
paragraphs: React controls radio buttons using state.
The checked attribute compares the state value with the radio value.

sections.question: Complete the code to handle a radio button:

sections.heading: Key Points
points: Radio buttons must share the same name attribute.
Use checked to control which option is selected.
Use state to store the selected value.
Radio buttons are controlled components in React.

sections.heading: Introduction
paragraphs: React Portals provide a way to render HTML outside the parent component's DOM hierarchy.
They are commonly used for modals, dialogs, tooltips, and floating UI elements.
Portals allow rendering UI in a different part of the DOM while keeping Reacts event system intact.

sections.heading: What are React Portals?
paragraphs: A Portal is a method provided by React in the react-dom package.
It allows rendering children into a DOM node that exists outside the parent component.
Normally, React components render inside their parent DOM structure.

sections.heading: Syntax
paragraphs: The createPortal method takes two arguments:
1. The React element to render
2. The DOM node where it should be rendered
sections.code: createPortal(children, domNode)

sections.heading: Using Portals for Modals
paragraphs: Portals are commonly used for modals that need to appear above all other elements.
They help avoid CSS issues such as overflow hidden or z-index conflicts.

sections.heading: Event Bubbling in Portals
paragraphs: Even though portals render outside the DOM hierarchy, React events still bubble through the component tree.
This means parent components can still handle events triggered inside a portal.

sections.heading: Why Use Portals
points: Avoid CSS overflow and z-index issues

sections.heading: Exercise
sections.question: What is the main purpose of React Portals?
options: To render content outside the parent component's DOM hierarchy
sections.answer: To render content outside the parent component's DOM hierarchy

sections.heading: Introduction
paragraphs: React Suspense lets you display alternative content while waiting for components or data to load.
It is commonly used with lazy loading and data fetching.
Suspense improves user experience by showing fallback UI during loading states.

sections.heading: What is Suspense?
paragraphs: Suspense is a React feature used to handle loading states in a declarative way.
It allows components to 'wait' while loading data or code.
During this time, React shows a fallback UI.

sections.heading: Basic Usage
paragraphs: Wrap a component inside Suspense.
Provide a fallback UI that appears while the component is loading.

sections.heading: Using Suspense with Lazy Loading
paragraphs: React.lazy() allows components to be loaded dynamically.
Suspense shows fallback content while the lazy-loaded component is being fetched.

sections.heading: Multiple Components
paragraphs: A single Suspense component can wrap multiple lazy-loaded components.
All wrapped components will share the same fallback UI.

sections.heading: Exercise
sections.question: What is the main purpose of React Suspense?
options: To display fallback content while components or data load
sections.answer: To display fallback content while components or data load

sections.heading: Introduction
paragraphs: There are several ways to style React components.
The most common approaches are inline styling, CSS stylesheets, and CSS Modules.

sections.heading: Inline Styling
paragraphs: Inline styling in React is done using JavaScript objects.
Styles are passed as an object to the style attribute.
CSS property names must be written in camelCase.

sections.heading: Camel Case Property Names
paragraphs: CSS properties written with hyphens must be converted to camelCase in React.
For example, background-color becomes backgroundColor.

sections.heading: Using a JavaScript Style Object
paragraphs: You can define styles as a JavaScript object and reuse them.
This improves readability and reusability.

sections.heading: CSS Stylesheet
paragraphs: You can write styles in a separate CSS file and import it into your component.
React automatically applies the styles when the file is imported.

sections.heading: CSS Modules
paragraphs: CSS Modules scope styles locally to a component.
They prevent class name conflicts.
CSS module files must use the .module.css extension.

sections.heading: Exercise
sections.question: What is the correct way to apply a JavaScript style object to an element?
sections.answer: Hello Style!

sections.heading: Introduction
paragraphs: CSS Modules allow you to write CSS that is scoped locally to a component.
This prevents class name conflicts and makes styles easier to maintain.
CSS Modules are supported by most React build tools.

sections.heading: What Are CSS Modules?
paragraphs: CSS Modules are CSS files where class names are locally scoped by default.
They must use the .module.css file extension.
Class names are automatically made unique.

sections.heading: Creating a CSS Module
paragraphs: Create a CSS file with the .module.css extension.
Define your styles inside the file.

sections.heading: Using a CSS Module
paragraphs: Import the CSS module as an object.
Use the class via the imported object.

sections.heading: Multiple Classes
paragraphs: You can combine multiple classes using template literals.
This allows reuse of base styles with variations.

sections.heading: Composing Classes
paragraphs: CSS Modules support class composition using the composes keyword.
This allows one class to inherit styles from another.

sections.heading: Global Classes
paragraphs: CSS Modules can define global styles using the :global keyword.
Global classes are not scoped and can be used anywhere.

sections.heading: Combining Global and Local Styles
paragraphs: You can mix global and local styles in the same CSS module.
Global classes are written with :global(), while local ones remain scoped.

sections.heading: Exercise
sections.question: What is the main purpose of CSS Modules in React?
options: To scope CSS classes locally to components
To merge all CSS into one file
sections.answer: To scope CSS classes locally to components

sections.heading: Introduction
paragraphs: CSS-in-JS is a styling technique where CSS is written directly inside JavaScript.
It allows styles to be scoped to components and avoids class name conflicts.
CSS-in-JS is commonly implemented using libraries like styled-components.

sections.heading: Getting Started
paragraphs: CSS-in-JS is not part of React core and must be installed separately.
The most popular library is styled-components.
It allows writing actual CSS inside JavaScript files.
sections.code: npm install styled-components

sections.heading: Basic Example
paragraphs: Styled components are created using tagged template literals.
CSS is written inside backticks.

sections.heading: Using Props in Styles
paragraphs: CSS-in-JS allows dynamic styling using component props.
This makes styling more flexible and reusable.

sections.heading: Extending Styled Components
paragraphs: Styled components can be extended to reuse styles.
This helps keep code clean and consistent.

sections.heading: Component Scoped Styles
paragraphs: CSS-in-JS automatically scopes styles to components.
Generated class names are unique.
This prevents style collisions across components.

sections.heading: Global Styles
paragraphs: Global styles can be created using createGlobalStyle.
These styles apply across the entire application.

sections.heading: Exercise
sections.question: What is a key benefit of CSS-in-JS in React?
options: Component-scoped styles with unique class names
sections.answer: Component-scoped styles with unique class names

sections.heading: Introduction
paragraphs: React Router is a library that provides routing capabilities for React applications.
Routing allows navigation between different views without reloading the page.
It is the standard routing solution for React single-page applications.

sections.heading: Why Use React Router
points: Create multiple pages in a single-page application

sections.heading: Installation
paragraphs: To use React Router, install the react-router-dom package.
sections.code: npm install react-router-dom

sections.heading: BrowserRouter Setup
paragraphs: Your application must be wrapped with BrowserRouter to enable routing.

sections.heading: Creating Pages
paragraphs: Each page is created as a separate component.

sections.heading: Basic Routing
paragraphs: React Router uses Link, Routes, and Route components.
Link is used for navigation.
Routes contain all route definitions.

sections.heading: Nested Routes
paragraphs: Nested routes allow rendering child components inside parent routes.
They are useful for layouts and sub-pages.

sections.heading: Exercise
sections.question: What is the main purpose of React Router?
options: To render content outside the DOM
sections.answer: To enable navigation between pages

sections.heading: Introduction
paragraphs: The useTransition hook helps keep React applications responsive during heavy updates.
It allows you to mark some state updates as non-urgent so urgent updates can happen first.

sections.heading: When to Use Transitions
points: When an operation is slow and may freeze the UI
When updates are not immediately important
When filtering or searching large lists

sections.heading: Basic Example
paragraphs: In this example, the input updates immediately while the search results update as a transition.

sections.heading: Real World Example
paragraphs: This example simulates a slow search by rendering many list items.

sections.heading: useTransition Hook
points: Returns an array with two values
isPending  indicates if a transition is running

sections.heading: Best Practices
points: Use transitions only for non-urgent updates
Do not wrap user typing or clicks unless needed
Great for filtering, searching, and large lists

sections.heading: Exercise
sections.question: What is the main purpose of the useTransition hook in React?
options: To mark state updates as non-urgent
sections.answer: To mark state updates as non-urgent

sections.heading: Introduction
paragraphs: The forwardRef API allows a parent component to pass a ref to a child component.
It is mainly used to access DOM elements inside child components.

sections.heading: Basic Example
paragraphs: This example demonstrates forwarding a ref to an input element.

sections.heading: How It Works
points: The ref is passed as the second parameter
The parent component can directly access the DOM element
Useful when you need imperative control

sections.heading: Important Notes
points: Most cases should use props and state instead
Works only with DOM elements or class components

sections.heading: Introduction
paragraphs: A Higher Order Component (HOC) is a function that takes a component and returns a new enhanced component.
It is used to reuse component logic without modifying the original component.

sections.heading: Key Concept
points: They take a component as input
They do not modify the original component
Used for reusable logic like authentication, logging, or styling

sections.heading: Example: Adding a Border
Explanation
points: withBorder is a Higher Order Component
It wraps another component inside a styled div
Props are passed using spread operator
Multiple enhanced versions can be created easily

sections.heading: Important Notes
points: Hooks can replace many HOC use cases
HOCs are still useful for cross-cutting concerns
Avoid overusing HOCs as they can make code harder to debug

sections.heading: Exercise
sections.question: What is a Higher Order Component (HOC) in React?
options: A component that renders multiple elements
A function that takes a component and returns a new enhanced component
A component with complex state management
sections.answer: A function that takes a component and returns a new enhanced component

sections.heading: Introduction
paragraphs: Sass is a CSS pre-processor.
Sass files are executed on the server and then converted into CSS.
Sass adds powerful features like variables, nesting, mixins, and functions.

sections.heading: Adding Sass to React
paragraphs: To use Sass in React, you must install the sass package.
After installation, you can import .scss files directly into your components.
sections.code: npm install sass

sections.heading: Creating a Sass File
paragraphs: Sass files use the .scss extension.
You can define variables and reuse them in styles.

sections.heading: Using Sass in React
paragraphs: Import the Sass file into your React component.
React will automatically compile Sass into CSS.

sections.heading: Sass Modules
paragraphs: Sass provides built-in modules such as sass:color.
These modules help manipulate colors and values dynamically.

sections.heading: Example with Multiple Headings
Important Notes
points: Sass files are compiled to CSS during build time
Variables make styling easier to manage

sections.question: Complete the SASS code to set the text color using the variable:

sections.heading: Introduction
paragraphs: Hooks allow functions to have access to state and other React features without using classes.
They provide a more direct API to React concepts like props, state, context, refs, and lifecycle.

sections.heading: What is a Hook?
paragraphs: Hooks are functions that let you "hook into" React state and lifecycle features from functional components.
Hooks do not work inside class components.

sections.heading: Basic Example
paragraphs: The useState Hook allows you to add state to a functional component.

sections.heading: Hook Rules
points: Hooks can only be called inside React function components.
Hooks must be called at the top level of a component.
Hooks do not work in class components.

sections.heading: Custom Hooks
paragraphs: Custom Hooks allow you to reuse stateful logic between components.
They are regular JavaScript functions that use React Hooks.
Their names must start with 'use'.

sections.heading: Key Points
points: Hooks simplify state management in React.
They replace the need for class components.
Hooks make code more readable and reusable.
useState is the most commonly used Hook.

sections.heading: Introduction
paragraphs: The useState Hook allows you to track state in a function component.
State refers to data or properties that need to be tracked in an application.

sections.heading: Importing useState
paragraphs: To use the useState Hook, you must import it from React.
useState is a named export.
sections.code: import { useState } from "react";

sections.heading: Initializing State
paragraphs: useState accepts an initial value and returns two values:
1. The current state
2. A function to update the state

sections.heading: Reading State
paragraphs: You can access the state variable directly inside JSX.

sections.heading: Updating State
paragraphs: State must be updated using the setter function.
Never modify state directly.

sections.heading: State Can Hold Any Data Type
paragraphs: State can store strings, numbers, booleans, arrays, and objects.
Multiple state hooks can be used in one component.

sections.heading: Using Objects in State
paragraphs: Instead of multiple state variables, you can use one object.

sections.heading: Updating Objects in State
paragraphs: When updating objects, the previous state must be preserved.
Use the JavaScript spread operator.

sections.heading: Key Points
points: useState is used to manage component state
State updates must use the setter function
State can store any data type
Objects must be updated immutably using spread operator
Multiple useState hooks can be used in one component

sections.heading: Exercise
sections.question: Which statement is used to initialize a state?
sections.answer: useState

sections.heading: Introduction
paragraphs: The useEffect Hook allows you to perform side effects in function components.
Side effects include fetching data, updating the DOM, timers, and subscriptions.

sections.heading: Syntax
paragraphs: useEffect accepts two arguments.
The second argument is optional and controls when the effect runs.

sections.heading: Basic Example
paragraphs: This example uses setTimeout to update state after 1 second.
Without a dependency array, useEffect runs after every render.

sections.heading: useEffect Dependency Types
paragraphs: There are three common ways to use dependencies with useEffect.

subsections.title: 2. Empty Dependency Array
subsections.description: Runs only once after the first render.

sections.heading: Example with Dependency
paragraphs: This example recalculates a value whenever count changes.

sections.heading: Effect Cleanup
paragraphs: Some effects require cleanup to prevent memory leaks.
Cleanup is done by returning a function inside useEffect.

sections.heading: Introduction
paragraphs: React Context is used to manage state globally.
It allows data to be shared between components without passing props manually.
The useContext Hook makes it easier to consume context values.

sections.heading: The Problem
paragraphs: Without context, data must be passed through multiple nested components.
This is called prop drilling.
Even components that do not use the data must pass it down.

sections.heading: Example Without Context
Creating Context
paragraphs: To create context, use the createContext function.
sections.code:
import { createContext } from 'react';

const UserContext = createContext();

sections.heading: Using Context Provider
paragraphs: The Provider component makes data available to child components.

sections.heading: Using useContext Hook
paragraphs: The useContext Hook is used to access context values.
It removes the need for prop drilling.

sections.heading: Complete Example
Why Use useContext?
points: Ideal for themes, authentication, language settings

sections.question: Complete the code to create and use a Context Provider:

sections.heading: Key Points
points: useContext is used to consume context values
Provider makes data available to children

sections.heading: Introduction
paragraphs: The useRef Hook allows you to persist values between renders.
It can store mutable values without causing a re-render.
It is commonly used to access DOM elements directly.

sections.heading: Does Not Cause Re-renders
paragraphs: Unlike useState, updating a useRef value does not trigger a re-render.
This makes it useful for tracking values like render counts.

sections.heading: How useRef Works
paragraphs: useRef returns an object with a single property called current.
The value persists across renders.
Updating current does not cause re-render.

sections.heading: Accessing DOM Elements
paragraphs: useRef is commonly used to access DOM elements directly.
The ref is attached using the ref attribute.

sections.heading: Tracking Previous State
paragraphs: useRef can store previous values without triggering re-renders.
This is useful for comparing old and new state values.

sections.heading: Exercise
sections.question: Complete the code to track render count using useRef:

sections.heading: Key Points
points: Updating ref does not re-render component
Returns an object with a current property

sections.heading: Introduction
paragraphs: The useReducer Hook is similar to useState.
It allows you to manage complex state logic.
It is useful when state depends on multiple actions or values.

sections.heading: Syntax
paragraphs: The useReducer Hook accepts three arguments:
1. reducer function
2. initial state
3. optional initializer function
sections.code: useReducer(reducer, initialState, init)

sections.heading: How It Works
paragraphs: The reducer function contains the logic for updating state.
The hook returns the current state and a dispatch function.
The dispatch function sends actions to the reducer.

sections.heading: Example: Score Counter
Why Use useReducer?
points: Useful when state depends on previous state
Good alternative to useState for complex updates

sections.heading: Exercise
sections.question: What is the main purpose of useReducer?
sections.answer: To handle complex state logic with multiple pieces of state

sections.heading: Key Points
points: useReducer is an alternative to useState
Uses reducer functions similar to Redux

sections.heading: Introduction
paragraphs: The useCallback Hook is used to memoize a callback function.
Memoization helps prevent unnecessary re-creation of functions.
It improves performance by avoiding unnecessary re-renders.

sections.heading: Purpose of useCallback
points: Prevents unnecessary re-rendering of child components
Useful when passing callbacks to memoized components
Works similarly to useMemo but returns a function

sections.heading: Syntax
sections.code: useCallback(callback, dependencies)

sections.heading: Explanation
paragraphs: callback: The function you want to memoize
dependencies: An array of values that determine when the function should be recreated
The function is recreated only when a dependency changes

sections.heading: Example Without useCallback
Example With useCallback
Why useCallback is Important
points: Useful for event handlers and callbacks

sections.heading: Exercise
sections.question: What is the main purpose of useCallback?
sections.answer: To memoize callback functions to prevent unnecessary re-renders

sections.heading: Introduction
paragraphs: The useMemo Hook returns a memoized value.
Memoization means caching a value so it does not need to be recalculated.
The value is only recalculated when its dependencies change.
This helps improve performance.

sections.heading: Difference Between useMemo and useCallback
points: Both are used to optimize performance

sections.heading: Problem Without useMemo
paragraphs: Without useMemo, expensive calculations run on every render.
This causes performance issues when unrelated state updates occur.

sections.heading: Example Without useMemo
Using useMemo
paragraphs: useMemo prevents unnecessary recalculations.
The function only runs when dependencies change.

sections.heading: Example With useMemo
Exercise
sections.question: What is the main purpose of useMemo?
sections.answer: To memoize values to prevent unnecessary recalculations

sections.heading: Key Points
points: Should be used for expensive calculations

They are JavaScript functions that start with the word 'use'.
Custom Hooks help keep components clean and reusable.

sections.heading: Example Without Custom Hook
paragraphs: Fetching logic is written directly inside the component.
This logic cannot easily be reused in other components.

sections.heading: Creating a Custom Hook

They allow logic reuse across components.
